title: 111_hr2222
content: The Act may be cited as the "Green Communities Act" and includes findings, purposes, and definitions. The "Green Communities Act" highlights the economic benefits of landscaping and greening urban areas. It emphasizes how landscaping can increase property values, reduce crime, and improve neighborhood stability. The Act aims to promote these benefits through various initiatives. The "Green Communities Act" aims to promote investment in greening projects as economic development tools, connect urban economic development with environmental initiatives, improve quality of life for city residents, and encourage public-private partnerships. Definitions in the Act include community greening initiatives, eligible nonprofit organizations, and eligible program partners. The "Green Communities Act" defines terms such as green roof, green stormwater infrastructure, nonprofit organization, and Secretary. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Commerce. Urban forestry is an integrated approach to tree planting, care, and management in cities or neighborhoods for environmental and social benefits. SEC. 3. INITIATIVES FOR ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AND GREENING. The Secretary will provide grants to municipalities for community greening initiatives. 80 municipalities will be selected based on specific criteria. Eligible program partners will work with nonprofit organizations to develop greening initiatives. The Secretary will provide grants to municipalities for community greening initiatives, including revitalizing parks, tree plantings, and green infrastructure projects. Grants will only be given to eligible partners who have successfully planned a greening initiative. The Secretary will provide grants up to $2,000,000 for community greening initiatives, with partners required to match at least 50% of the grant amount. Initiatives must be completed within 2 years, and partners must submit a report within 60 days of receiving the grant. The eligible nonprofit organization must submit a report to the Secretary within 60 days after a community greening initiative is implemented by an eligible program partner. SEC. 4. Technical assistance and training provided by eligible nonprofit organizations. The Secretary will select 5 nonprofit organizations with experience in urban open space projects, land conservation, community partnerships, and urban ecology to provide technical assistance and training to eligible program partners. Eligible nonprofit organizations will offer training for various activities as outlined in section 3(c). The Secretary will select 5 nonprofit organizations to provide technical assistance and training for community greening initiatives, workshops for municipal agencies, and evaluating the initiatives. Grants or agreements will be for a 5-year period, with reports to Congress on the assistance provided. Authorization of appropriations for the selected nonprofit organizations to provide technical assistance and training for community greening initiatives. Authorization of appropriations for eligible nonprofit organizations to provide technical assistance and training for community greening initiatives. $30,000,000 authorized for fiscal years 2010, 2013, and 2014, and $90,000,000 for fiscal years 2011 and 2012. At least 85% of funds for 2010, 2013, and 2014, and 28% for 2011 and 2012, to be allocated for technical assistance and training by eligible nonprofit organizations. Funds under the Act will support community greening initiatives by eligible program partners. At least 66 percent of funds for fiscal years 2011 and 2012 will be allocated for this purpose. The appropriations will remain available until expended.
